content: Chapter 10 discharge? Which one is that, hardship or discharge in lieu of courts martial? Now, I am not and was not a recruiter, however, I know that when a prospective recruit did not graduate, they were required to notify the recruiter, and the recruiter had to foward that information on to MEPS, where a determination was made to either extend the recruit in the DEP program to permit them to meet qualifications, or to remove them from the program. Next, did you sign a contract or not? It sounds silly, but until your signature is on the bottom line, you are not part of the military, or such is my understanding. Really, the best advice I can give you is to look at the discharge form you recieved, DD214 I assume is standard for all levels of the military. See how it defines your separation, if it falls into the General under honorable condition or honorable discharge types, I would not worry about it. If it fall under anything else, you may want to see about getting it changed, which can be a long, hard, and sometimes impossible task. To request a change in your discharge, you will need to submit an "Application for the Review of Discharge From the Armed Forces of the United States" DD293 You may want to get a professional to help with filling out and submitting it, but you may have a bit of saving grace as well, since you were separated after 1 OCT 1982, and were in an entry level status, if your discharge is an Other Than Honorable, you can request it be changed to "Uncharacterized" by reason of "Entry Level Separation" I hope this helps you out some. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: I'm confused. You say you were in the DEP, but never fulfilled your obligation to enter the service, right? If you didn't sign a service contract and stand and be sworn in for active duty, you were never in the service. If you didn't graduate or graduated at a later date and didn't perform the above, you were never in the service, because once you signed and were sworn in, they packed you out for Boot Camp immediately. Did you have a lawyer provided by the Staff Judge Advocate or did you have your own? He/she should have explained everything to you, before you ever signed anything or said anything. Somewhere along the line, there has been a mistake and I'm not sure this really occured in the way you say it did. There has to be more to this story, like maybe you signed your contract, got sworn in and then took off and they just now caught up to you. If it happened the way you say it did, you got screwed.

content: Not sure what the Chapter 10 is about but I agree with Anchorman, until you signed on the line, you couldn't be court martialed as you were not a part of the military. This document may help you (PDF) <<<http://www.usarec.army.mil/im/formpub/REC_PUBS/R601_56.pdf>>> pages 6 and 7 show that procedure requires that you be notified that you failed to report on your scheduled date a nd that they then have to go through a process of checking on what happened and either extend or seperate you. Your seperation code should be ZDA from AR 135-178, paragraph 15-8. There should have been a seperation request filed (page 13) but your recruiter(?) would have needed to talk to your high school either by phone or in a formal letter from the high school explaining the situation. You should have also received after all of that was filed a void Enlistment Packet. I'm not a recruiter by any means, but from everything I can see there was no reason for a court martial. You may want to take your file back to the recuiter's office and see if they can help you sort through it.

content: I don't understand this - How can a kid, who has never been sworn in, be punished under the UCMJ? Am I missing something here, or are we talking about a MINOR when the paper was signed? Can a Juvenile be handled this way without a travesty of justice taking place? YES, get a Lawyer and HAMMER this practice. There is some major unethical wool being pulled over somebody's eyes. Did the kid screw up? Yes. Do juveniles screw up because they don't see the big picture? Yes. Should this result in a permanent black mark on the record? No! "Note what this means. It means that if an applicant failed to show up to ship out to basic training, the military COULD order the individual to active duty. If the individual refused, the military could legally court-martial the individual, if they wanted to. Now, let's talk reality. This never happens. Never. Not a single person has been involuntarily ordered to active duty, court-martialed, or otherwise prosecuted in civilian courts for being in the DEP and refusing to ship out to boot camp in *AT LEAST* the past 27 years. Not one single person." Did you "refuse" an order to report? Why not just report for duty, and the Army can work you through GED program - - Put the responsibility back on the military by saying, "Here I am, ready to serve. Now what!?" It don't take a HS Diploma to shoot an enemy with an M-16... Wandering and Wondering

content: Not sure what the Chapter 10 is about but I agree with Anchorman, until you signed on the line, you couldn't be court martialed as you were not a part of the military. This document may help you (PDF) <<<http://www.usarec.army.mil/im/formpub/REC_PUBS/R601_56.pdf>>> pages 6 and 7 show that procedure requires that you be notified that you failed to report on your scheduled date a nd that they then have to go through a process of checking on what happened and either extend or seperate you. Your seperation code should be ZDA from AR 135-178, paragraph 15-8. There should have been a seperation request filed (page 13) but your recruiter(?) would have needed to talk to your high school either by phone or in a formal letter from the high school explaining the situation. You should have also received after all of that was filed a void Enlistment Packet. I'm not a recruiter by any means, but from everything I can see there was no reason for a court martial. You may want to take your file back to the recuiter's office and see if they can help you sort through it.

content: I don't understand this - How can a kid, who has never been sworn in, be punished under the UCMJ? Am I missing something here, or are we talking about a MINOR when the paper was signed? Can a Juvenile be handled this way without a travesty of justice taking place? YES, get a Lawyer and HAMMER this practice. There is some major unethical wool being pulled over somebody's eyes. Did the kid screw up? Yes. Do juveniles screw up because they don't see the big picture? Yes. Should this result in a permanent black mark on the record? No! "Note what this means. It means that if an applicant failed to show up to ship out to basic training, the military COULD order the individual to active duty. If the individual refused, the military could legally court-martial the individual, if they wanted to. Now, let's talk reality. This never happens. Never. Not a single person has been involuntarily ordered to active duty, court-martialed, or otherwise prosecuted in civilian courts for being in the DEP and refusing to ship out to boot camp in *AT LEAST* the past 27 years. Not one single person." Did you "refuse" an order to report? Why not just report for duty, and the Army can work you through GED program - - Put the responsibility back on the military by saying, "Here I am, ready to serve. Now what!?" It don't take a HS Diploma to shoot an enemy with an M-16... Wandering and Wondering
